Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities

abstract.p: Newly expanded Imperial War Museum in London opens permanent exhibit dedicated to Holocaust and centered on persecution of European Jews; photo (M)

block.p: A permanent exhibit devoted to the Holocaust has opened in a new five-floor wing of London's Imperial War Museum.

The main focus of the exhibit, which takes up 13,000 square feet of space on two floors, is the persecution of European Jews, beginning with the turbulent post-World War I period when radical movements were flourishing on both left and right.
A permanent exhibit devoted to the Holocaust has opened in a new five-floor wing of London's Imperial War Museum.

The main focus of the exhibit, which takes up 13,000 square feet of space on two floors, is the persecution of European Jews, beginning with the turbulent post-World War I period when radical movements were flourishing on both left and right.

Persecution of other groups, such as Gypsies, Poles, Soviet prisoners of war, people with disabilities, homosexuals and prisoners of conscience, is also addressed in the exhibits, which include photographs, documents, newspapers, posters, archival film and interviews with Holocaust survivors.

Sections are entitled Jewish life before the Nazis; Euthanasia; News Reaches Britain; Invasion of the Soviet Union; Jewish Armed Resistance; Inside the Camps; Rescue and Survival; Destroying the Evidence; and War Crimes Trials.

Among the exhibits are a deportation railroad car acquired from Belgian Railways and a funeral cart used in the Warsaw ghetto. Also on view are personal mementoes, letters, diaries, family photographs and concentration camp uniforms. There is also a model of Auschwitz 40 feet long.

Imperial War Museum, Lambeth Road, London SE1 6HZ; (44-891) 600-140 (recorded information), (44-207) 416-5320; www.iwm.org.uk. The museum is open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily, exhibit from 10:15 a.m. to 5 p.m. Not recommended for children under 14. Admission $8.35; free for children under 16 and seniors. Advance booking is advisable on (44-207) 416-5439.
